prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO3-2 PACSMS02 & PACSMS10
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO3-2 mapping of PACSMS02 and PACSMS10

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We estimated the CO integrated flux of our sources from their SFR and redshift following Sargent et al. (2014). Two of these sources (PACSMS28 and PACSMS03) were observed in compact configuration by PdBI and confirmed the validity of our predictions (compatible at 1sigma). Depending on the redshift of our sources, we target CO2-1 or CO3-2. The flux ratio between these lines and CO1-0 is estimated using Daddi et al. (2014). We assume a rectangular profile and a line width of 400km/s. We compute the sensitivity in the same bandwidth. We found similar spatially-integrated flux densities of ~3 mJy for our four galaxies. This value is a lower limit. The value of 400 km/s is a maximum and the line should be narrower by a factor of X. The flux density at the peak flux density would thus be X times higher. However, the noise in a X time narrower band will be sqrt(X) higher. We could thus have a sqrt(X) time better S/N. Our estimate is thus conservative and we can thus expect a slightly higher signal-to-noise ratio.
We have however to take into account that this flux will be split between several beams. The typical extension of our galaxies is typically 1 and we chose a resolution of ~0.5 (see justification in the imaging part). We thus request a 0.15 mJy/beam sensitivity to get a 5 sigma detection in 4 beam elements. 2 sources (PACSMS02 and PACSMS10) can be observed with the same tuning, reducing slightly the overheads. This is not the case for the two other sources. The band 3 observations are thus performed using 3 different science goals.
We checked that this strategy is reasonable producing a simulated image of our sources assuming that the CO distribution will follow the I-band flux (see Fig. 2). The disk and some isolated clumps are well detected on this image. We can expect that the bulge will be fainter in real data. The disk could thus be brighter and the source may look more extended in the real ALMA data. As instance, in PACSMS02, 03 and 28, the disk in only marginally detected on the simulation and the bulge is booming. This could be the contrary in the real data. Finally, we could expect from theoretical predictions that one or two clumps concentrate a major fraction of the gas. If this is correct, they should be detected in the ALMA data (e.g. we already see some characteristic shapes in PACSMS28). If these clumps are more numerous, there could be an effect of confusion, but the clumpiness could be characterized through the fluctuations of density across the disk.
The signal-to-noise of in 1/3 of the line width is only 2.9 for a width of 400 km/s. Velocity dispersion measurements could thus be difficult. However, as explained in the first paragraph, the line should be slightly narrower with a higher peak flux density. The S/N should thus be much better.
The dust continuum cannot be detected in band 3 without a very long integration. We thus use complementary observation in band 6 to detect it.

We choose to use the FDM with a binning by a factor of 16 (maximum possible) in spectral windows where we expect the detection of a line. This will allow a resolution of ~30 km/s. This is an order of magnitude high than the width of 400km/s used to compute the sensitivity. However, this value is an upper limit and we do not want to lose information if the line would be surprisingly narrow. As instance, some clumpy structures could have significantly lower velocity dispersion and could be spectrally-unresolved with the TDM (~100 km/s channels).
We use the TDM in the other spectral windows to try to detect the continuum. However, only upper limits are expected.

We want to spatially resolve our sources. However, going to too high resolution would spread the flux of the galaxies into two many beams and requests a too long integration time. We choose 0.5 arcsec as compromise. In band 3, this resolution corresponds to the most extended configuration allowed in standard mode of observation (C36-5, baseline<2 km).
The justification of the sensitivity requirements are detailed in the science goal CO3-2 PACSMS02 & PACSMS10 and are not copied here to avoid redundancy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Continuum + high J CO (3 objects) + CI (2 objects)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Continuum of the four objects in band 6. 3 high-J CO transition. 2 CI transitions.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We estimated the flux of the continuum in band 3 using Magdis et al. (2012) MS templates and found that the continuum signal in a 7.5 Ghz bandwidth at the chosen depth of our observations will be only ~1sigma/beam for our four sources. We thus request an additional band-6 observation to detect the continuum with a S/N and resolution similar to the CO in band 3. Since the necessary integration time is short (~5min per source), we use a single tuning for all the sources to minimize the calibration overheads. The expected total integrated flux of the faintest object is 1.3 mJy. We thus need a sensitivity of 0.065 mJy/beam to match the criterion of 5sigma in 4 beams used for CO in band 3.
We tune the setting of the band in order to cover the range 256.9 and 259.036 GHz where some bright lines are expected (CO76 and CI 3P2-1 for PACSMS02 and PACSMS10, CO65 for PACSMS28). The flux density (in mJy) of the CO7-6 and CO6-5 lines is expected to be ~2 times brighter than CO2-1 (e.g. Daddi et al. 2014) and we should thus detect it at 3 sigma in 1/3 of the source line width (5.3 sigma in the full line width). CI is expected to have approximately half of the flux of CO7-6 and will be detected only if the line width is narrower than the assumed 400km/s or the line is brigther. If detected, these lines will be very helpful to improve the dynamical modeling of our objects in combination with band 3 data.
The main scientific goal of the band 6 is the continuum. We thus chose to use the TDM. The resolution of 30 km/s matches the resolution we requested in band 3 in channels where we have lines.
We chose to have the same resolution in band 3 and 6, since one of our scientific goals is to compare the spatial distribution of dust (band 6) and gas (band 3).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Deep Herschel surveys have revealed a population of very-massive (few 10^11 Msun), intensely-star-forming (200-500 Msun/yr) galaxies at the massive-end of the famous "main-sequence" at z=2, when the star formation rate density in the Universe was maximum. Understanding the physical processes driving such intense star formation is a difficult challenge. In addition, statistical studies show that these galaxies will stop to form stars soon and that they are hosted by massive halos, what are progenitors of today's clusters. This population could thus be a key to understand the formation of massive, passive galaxies at high redshift. To better understand their nature, we propose to perform a low-resolution imaging of the dust (traced by continuum) and gas (traced by CO) for a pilot sample of four galaxies. These data will address several hot questions: can the intense star formation in these objects be explained only by large gas reservoirs? How is the gas and dust distributed (disk vs bulge, presence of clumps)? Are these objects rotation- or dispersion-dominated? Is their alphaCO factor closer from local spiral or starbursts? Do their environment contain star-forming satellites?
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: This is a resubmission of the cycle 2 proposal 2013.1.00914.S. This proposal was accepted as a filler (C priority). No observation was performed at the time we submitted this proposal. The science and technical justifications were updated. The observing strategy did not change since the cycle 2 proposal, but total time decreases from 4.8h to 3.6h.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics & Astronomy, Sussex, University of
